I have to say, i've been playing since a lot to videogames, even something more on the hardcore side, or difficult games, fromsoftware and rogues, but never, NEVER i had to give something up EXCEPT this game because of how hard it's scripted. This phantom has been hunting this game and the back of my head for a lot since i've started, but in my last campaign, i just had enough. On year 1 of a Schalke 04 campaign, i ended up, luckily, to the semifinals of DFB - Pokal by knocking out Borussia Dortmund, which i thought was a lost cause. In this semi-final, i was up against Bayern Munchen. Now, i don't savescum or stuff in this game, except when i missclick something, but this time i decided that i wanted to win this round by force and then lose or whatever in the finals, just cause i thought Bundesliga would have been less boring without Bayern continously winning over and over, and by having Eintracht Frankfurt or Wolfsburg win the DFB Pokal, they would have had a little boost of money to become more threatening next year. Well, guess what. I have, by now, replayed the game against Bayern Munchen 90 times. YES: 90 TIMES. It did not matter the tactics, modules, substitutions, score at the end of the first time. NOTHING. EVER. DID. BAYERN WON EVERY SINGLE MATCH WE PLAYED WITHOUT MOVING AN INCH. Now, we all know how pretentious or hard it may sound from a Bundesliga 2 team to beat such a giant, but still, considering i unexpectedly won against a top tier team like Dortmund, and that in real life, Bayern even lost at round 2 by a Bundesliga 3 team, plus considering the fact that this game is SUPPOSED to include some degree of rng, i expected to win, even by a miracle, just once against Bayern, and at a certain point i just refused to give that game up and started truly experimenting how hard Football Manager series is scripted, and that's the conclusion: 90 GAMES, 90 DEFEATS. I don't know if i'll keep trying this madness or just drop the game entirely since it's so blatantly scripted it makes any normal player puke, but at least i'll just share my experience with you so that you'll know what will be expecting you inside every game of the series. Viewer discretion advised.

The Football Manager series has lots of pros, like some depth and tons of replayablility, but its cons are obnoxious enough to merit a downvote as far as I'm concerned. My biggest gripe with the series is that it is released every single year as a new game with a AAA price tag. Do the annual upgrades or additions justify a AAA price tag of a new game? Not even remotely. This, alone, is so low, obnoxious, unethical, lazy, and predatory that it deserves a hundred thousand downvotes.

Other cons for the game include bad optimization or lack of responsiveness, regular loading times that definitely could've been eliminated or at least shortened with smarter code, outdated graphics, horrendous animations, and an obvious lack of user-friendliness in the UI design, like too many clicks to achieve things that could've been achieved with half the clicks if the developing company stops being greedy and hires competitive UI, UX, and user-friendly design experts to help design the interface and the whole game.

The main reason for the ratings being generally positive on Steam is the addictive nature of the game for some players, which makes those poor addicts keep buying the game for full price annually instead of demanding these crumbs of improvements as DLCs or expansions. The second reason is the players who try the game for the first time and give it a thumbs up; those are justified in their rating sometimes, but I hope that they change their rating once they realize that there are zero expansions, and next year's release shows up with the predatory price tag that hits them in the face and wakes them up from the addictive stupor. Oh, but even then, it could be too late to raise awareness about this scheme, because the developer asks Steam to hide the older Football Manager games from searches and only show the current year's release with every new release. You know, just in case you had any suspicions about their predatory policies.

If you are a diehard fan of soccer or football itself and its players, which is one of the main reasons you would play this game, then I don't think I can benefit you beyond what I wrote above plus adding that you may want to buy an older key for the cheapest price possible or try the game as part of a game pass to which you subscribe for [other] reasons. Football Manager 2022, for example, would allow you to experience everything worth experiencing in this series without paying the highest price for the current year's release. However, if you like these types of games generally, my strong advice instead is to try, put your money in, and play Cities: Skylines. It is an even deeper strategy game with [actual] graphics and from a much more ethical developer.

I'm not really a sports fan, only a casual one. Football is one of the few sports that I occasionally enjoy. This game is not for me. It is for people that are hardcore into clubs and who want to get deep into it's management side. So when you read the following, remember that my opinion is based on me not really caring too much about the sport and that I expect somewhat more casual gameplay.

I tried to like this game, and tried it twice. First for 10 min then refunded it, the second time I watched some startup tutorials and got it again and tried it until my first season practice match, then refunded it.

I still could not deal with it. Way back in the day I had played the "original" Football Manager on Commodore. It was basically Pong with more bars, and some basic management of the bars (the players). Google Pong if you have to. No not bong..., Pong! 

Management back then was simple, you sold and bought players, stadiums, and some other few basic things, that was it. It was mainly about the matches. Matches made money, you could buy better players, won more matches made more money bought more players, you could play it half asleep and still win. 

In this here game you can delegate a lot of the "boring" management but then you lose control over what is going on and after a seemingly endless time of just clicking through a flood of management tasks and choices to make it, finally culminates in a match. The management is pretty deep, the media is on you all the time with their opinions, the players aren't doing their jobs unless you give them an encouraging slap around and there are lots of fluff tasks that give content to your every day inbox.

I was ready to deal with all the clickery, having gotten the impression that at least the matches would be very well animated (as that seemed to be advertised and reviews from fans had said that the realism of the matches was at the highest level so far seen.)

When I finally managed to "yes to everything"-myself to the first match the big disappointment came. 

It felt kind of lifeless. The options for how a match was shown felt unintuitive. I could either watch the entire match in whole (90 mins!), or let it be shown in different types highlight cuts that didn't make much sense to me, (not even their nomenclature made much sense). The players moved in a typical computer animated way (not really that fluently), the passes were very linear, the animations seemed few, the audio seemed to be taken (yet upsampled) from the original FM from the Commodore, (especially the kicks, all sounded exactly the same, with exactly the same volume every time) it was just annoying! The graphics weren't what you could expect from this day and age either and I had maxed everything out.

I don't know, I expected better. This is not a cheap game! This is still basically a text based game after all. Not really much effort had been spent on the match graphics and animation, and the sound is absolutely sub par and seriously on a level from 30 years ago. This is definitely a cash cow, which is actually kind of typical for EA. High price for lackluster content.

If you love the sport and want to feel you're doing something meeningful in your spare time, good for you, you probably enjoy this. But for someone like me who wants to just casually fiddle with a team and pretend to watch a leage on demand where the team you cheer for eventually wins, it's not good. Not for what you get, not at that price, and for that it feels like I'm back at work, as it seriously feels like work. I prefer to leave the job at work and relax at home. 

And even for people exited for this kind of game a more realistic price would be $15. That's it. Compare how much work must have been put into one of the later Assassins Creeds, compared with making a graphical interface for a lot of databases, some counters, some randomizers, slap on some shoddy 3D graphics where you don't even control anything as the gamer, add a little bit of freeware sound effects and you're done. Nah... you are being robbed. 

Think before you buy, and watch tutorials on how to start it up, because you will without a doubt have to spend many hours getting through the first management phase until you get a bit of a feel for the game and by then you might well have passed the refund time. I can bet EA made it so on purpose so you wouldn't get a good feel for the first whole game cycle before 2 hours (more like 4-6) so you couldn't refund it in time. EA put more effort into making it non-refundable than into the matches. Sad but typical EA. Don't buy if you aren't a football nerd with at least level 90.

Do I like the game? Yes. Do I recommend buying this game or the next installment? No. Let me explain.

I've played almost every version of this game, starting with the Championship Manager series. The game has changed so much over time, and for the most part the changes have been improvements. That having said, looking at recent years, a lot of changes have not been improvements and the focus is on the wrong things.

I'm not going to beat around the bush. The graphics are bad for a 2022 game from a big developer. You can bring all the arguments to the table that you want, it doesn't change the fact that the graphics are simply not good. I, too, celebrated when the graphics changed from 2D to 3D and I thought it looked good at the time. Years later, and the graphics have not improved at all. Any other game, literally any other game in any series has improved their graphics, except Football Manager. You may argue that FM is not about the graphics and that its power lies in being an amazing "spreadsheet manager". However, years ago, they put all that effort into creating a 3D engine, so I would argue that SEGA does care about the graphics, but they put their energy elsewhere. Which brings me back to my original point; the focus is on the wrong things.

I see new features and announcements of changes in the media interviews, more data, a deadline day feature, squad dynamics. Do these things really improve the game? Are they features that people keep using? That people keep coming back for? I've used the deadline day feature and don't see the appeal. I don't see how it makes the game better. More data? More dynamics? You can have all the data and statistics you want but you can still simply download a tactic from the internet and go an entire season unbeaten. With a downloaded tactic. One tactic that fits all. And no you don't have to pay attention to dynamics, or pay attention to training, or the data hub, or all the added statistics, just get a tactic from the web and you're good. Is it wrong when a downloaded tactic can do that? No. But it doesn't make sense to keep adding stuff and features around statistics, information, more buttons, etc. etc. when all you really need is a good tactic.

Meanwhile, the game looks like it was made for the PS1. 

To put it into perspective; PES Club Manager had better graphics (unreal engine) and was just as enjoyable. It was all about managing your club, had plenty of tactic tweaking and statistics, but didn't go overboard with it. And the matches were fun to watch. It makes me sad to think a mobile game looked better than one of my favorite series of all time.

This is why I don't recommend buying this game. And I won't be buying FM23. 

The game has plenty of features. The game has plenty of data and statistics. Let's focus on the graphics once again. Let's try to make the game look good. It doesn't need a yearly graphics update, but man, it's been 13 years since we first saw this 3D engine.

As an avid FM player for the past seven editions, I am sad to say that this is by far the worst FM I've ever played. It feels like this is a buggy early beta build, not a fully released product. The match engine is the most unrealistic so far, with the only viable tactics in most situations being some form of pressing, short passing system even in lower leagues where this type of tactic shouldn't be possible. No matter what happens, even the worst teams in the league have completion percentages of 85% or higher, which if you know anything about football you'd recognize as being a bit absurd (maybe that would be normal for the best teams, but when the worst team in the sixth tier of English football is passing with 90% accuracy, you know something is wrong). Sometimes defenders decide to just wander off and are nowhere near the play. You can't play with anything other than a high defensive line, as crosses are way too effective this year. The transfer system is a bit of a mess, with players complaining about asking prices even when the interface says they should be happy with the asking price. I've had players throw a tantrum about their price being too high when a dozen teams were willing to meet it and the agent said it should be fine. Expected playing time vs accurate playing time is glitched, and sometimes the player who has started each of the dozen league games you've played so far will complain because the game thinks they're only being used as a squad player. Then there's features like "dynamic youth rating" which were misrepresented by SI (youth rating doesn't actually change except for very rare circumstances), who then give snappy responses when called out on it. SI's reaction as a whole to any criticism of the game or reports of bugs usually boil down to "not a bug, you just don't like our game being realistic", even when it's clearly an unrealistic bug, which is disappointing coming from a developer who is usually very good about interacting with the game's community. Football Manager is a stellar series of games and '22 is no different. There have been massive updates to the match engine and it's beginning to feel more and more realistic with each year. 

There are some problems with it though. The dynamics/player interactions system is completely screwed. Players will get angry at the littlest of things, and often you are walking a tight rope when interacting with your players. The transfer-list value is completely screwed, and your players will come to you if you offer them out for even the most minute discrepancies in value. Keeping your players happy while also winning is far more difficult than it should be. This area of the game is more like a dating sim than a football sim.

In the same boat, the transfers this year seem like a complete toss up. It really feels like it's down to luck trying to either sell players for their value or get players for a fair value. Loans seem to be near impossible to secure without a senior affiliate. 

The staff meetings are completely useless. All they've done is taken what used to be a single email and put it in a long step-by-step meeting thing that takes far longer than it needs to. If you like to get really involved in the game, often times they will suggest things that aren't helpful or opposite to what you're trying to do (i.e. get a player to train a completely different skillset to what you need). 

The same goes for the transfer window meetings. I'd personally rather it just come up in the scouting email.

For each thing I dislike about the game there's about 100 I love, so take these with a grain of salt. But this year the improvements outside of the match engine don't really feel like improvements at all.

It's still definitely worth buying and a lot of fun.

I generally recommend the game if you want to risk your private life. It's negative because the review will get more attention and I have a few things to point out.

If you are or will become an FM player you will be able to answer those questions:

1. Your team is first in the league, you are well prepared, have maximum morale and will face the last team in the league on your territory. What will happen?
a) Of course you will win
b) It will be an even match
c) The worst team in the lague will stomp you 3-0.

2. What does Offensive and Defensive mentality do?
a) Offensive means you will shoot on goal more giving you more chances and Defensive means rival team will have more trouble scoring.
b) The opposite.

3. Can a player be mad at you of you praise his good performance?
a) No, that can't be.
b) Yes he can.

4. Is it possible to have rival team scoring penalties against you 4 matches in a row?
a) No, there's surely an option to tell players to be extremely careful.
b) Yes there is such a possibility and it's not that rare.

5. Is it possible to predict when enemy team will score?
a) No, just like in real life, football can be unpredictable.
b) Yes, you sometimes know when enemy team will score and you can do nothing about it.

6. Is it a comming thing for the Goalkeeper to pass directly to the Striker, and the Striker to run alone at the goal to score?
a) Probably extremely rare.
b) Probably happens sometimes, especially when your defenders suck.
c) It's a common way to lose goals and lose matches.

FM is now FIFA. It's clear that SI are investing as little development into each edition as they can get away with. Comments elsewhere have suggested that the fair solution (for gamers) would be releasing a patch every season with an update of players rather than a whole new game. As can be seen, I've given plenty of hours to this edition so I think it's fair to say that these observations are based on a significant amount of experience with the game. 

1) Transfers. With each edition, this gets more and more skewed in favour of the AI. You will rarely if ever sell a player for close to their valuation, yet any attempts to purchase an AI player for less will be rejected. The loan system is even worse, with negotiations only possible on your loanees, not on an AIs. 

2) ME. The match engine hasn't improved and with every patch, something changes to ruin your previously developed tactic. There was a brief moment when FM22 came out that strikers finished one on ones, but that was clearly too realistic for SI so that was 'fixed'. Also good luck defending against the inevitable 30 yard effort from the opposition player who hasn't scored all season...

3) Other: The game is riddled with annoying little flaws; the board scores are ridiculous, the inability to negotiate objectives is infuriating and a backwards step from previous versions... don't even get me started on the "dynamic youth rating"! 

In conclusion, I don't feel I can recommend this game anymore. I've had every edition since the switch to FM and it is without a doubt that there has been little actual improvement in the way the game plays. Yes, there's been "new features", though the usefulness of the analysis is dubious given the inevitability of some of the match engine gameplay. Unless FM23 offers a radical overhaul and massive improvement in the areas above, I think my time playing this game is over and that is one of the saddest realisations a gamer can have!

This game is a drug and I'll probably dump another 1000 hours into it because I'm a hopeless addict. But I'm not happy with the direction Football Manager has been going in with the past few versions.

I recently fired up FM17 out of curiosity, and found the experience so much more streamlined. No more meetings that could have been emails. No more performance evaluations with the owners about whether I'd signed enough Portuguese players. No more forcing the latest updates from the Canadian Premier League down my throat by automatically going to the News and Around The World pages. Less staff members with vague titles whose jobs I don't understand. No more debriefings after meetings telling me "Actually players don't like being yelled at." FM17 ran faster, so less downtime waiting for the game to process. FM17 allowed me to focus on the core engagements of the game - trying to fit tactics to teams, finding and signing talent, developing players, and a reasonable amount of man management. FM22 is certainly more realistic. But that realism looks suspiciously like an actual job.

There are aspects of FM22 that I missed. Dynamic youth rating is definitely an intriguing feature, even if its implementation is contentious (I think it was correctly implemented, but clearly some people disagree). The player valuation system and transfer market is much improved. I do like that player development is more variable, even if in the moment it's frustrating when the wonderkid I'd put all my hope in doesn't turn out. All these require a level of adaptability previous versions of FM just didn't ask of you. And while FM17's five year old database is a fun nostalgia trip, at some point I'll want to return to present day. I very well may return to FM22. Certainly nothing is a total deal breaker with it. But it's become clear that SI have built a bloated mess with a terrible UX and it's really tempered my enthusiasm for this franchise I've been playing for the last decade.

It's 2051. LOSC Lille are playing in the final of the Coupe de France, a competition they haven't won for 4 decades. 5 years ago, they were in Ligue 2. Yet here they are, in the final of a major competition after so long. It's tied, 0-0. The opposition, perennial title contenders Olympique Lyonnais, had dominated the match up until star midfielder Alexandru-Mihai got sent off in the 69th minute. Since then, it's been in deadlock, no side offering much offensively. LOSC striker Koutan gets a strike chalked off in the 84th for offside, and now it's in extra time. It passes quickly, no chances either side. That is, until the 119th minute of 120.

Pierre Gicquel was born in Lille in 2033. For all his 17 years, he'd loved the club. His parents recalled the glory days of the club to him, culminating in title glory in 2021. His entire life, he'd dreamed of being the one to restore his club to greatness, to have the captain's armband while carrying the team to national, even worldwide, glory. From a young age, the staff at LOSC knew he was special, even being touted as the next Kylian Mbappe. Small, a mere 5'7, but incredibly agile, he started out as a striker but quickly found his place as a winger. He tore up every youth division he played in. Now, here he is, 17 and it's his first professional season for the club. Gicquel has played a big part in the team's first title challenge since 2021, but to start the cup final, he was on the bench.

With the minutes winding down in extra time, LOSC's Dutch winger Ibrahim Jabbie was exhausted, and there was an obvious choice waiting in the wings. Gicquel stepped on the pitch, and if the weight of a city was on his shoulders, he didn't show it. 

It's the 119th minute. There's 1 minute of added time. It's the last attack of the game. Gicquel and right-back Balek are exchanging passes on the wing. Suddenly, a hole appears. Gicquel sees it, and swiftly dodges inside before the defenders can react. He cuts to the edge of the box. He's on his weaker left foot. He doesn't care. He's 25 yards out. He doesn't care. All he cares about is this city, this stadium, the one he grew up in the shadow of. The stadium whose visitors now all stare at him in awe. This club, the one he's been sitting in front of the TV, watching, supporting, following, for every day of his life. 

Pierre Gicquel strikes the ball. Everyone in the building knows where it's going. Top corner. Completely unsaveable.

Gicquel became a LOSC legend that day. Everyone knows that someday he might grow up, he might leave, he might even force his way out. None of that matters. On one sunny day in May 2051, football was the winner, and Gicquel was its vessel. Perhaps it's just a game. But in that fateful moment, that game changed lives, and gave the world a story to be told for generations to come.

The game remains to this day very buggy, the Pre-Game Editor remains to this day broken and several important features are unusable as they ruin the data with any change you make and the game overall feels more like a full time job than a video game, with unnecessary time consuming features that add no flavour to the game, the User Interface has taken a nosedive since FM20 with information scrambled around the screen rather than focused in one place. 

Overall the game is worth the trouble only if you do not have an earlier version. I prefer playing older versions like FM09, FM12, FM20 than spending my time with this one.

I wanted to give it a fair shot as this is the first review I write, but I can imagine that several important bugs that have been flagged from Day 1 will remain unresolved with the next update. Overall:
You will manage various characters with attitude and ego that strives to make you mad.
You will experiment with different tactics and strategy to find the OP strat before enemy somehow learns how to break it and make you repeat the loop again.
You will fight enemies with more money, better stats/skills, and often able to charm away your best characters with money.
You will have people expecting you to defeat stronger enemies, win all challenges, and eventually dominate the world.
You will be a hero...oh wai- I mean a football manager (again)! 

Side note - I skipped FM2021 so this will be a considerable change from FM2020. Overall, it is fresh enough for me but I probably wouldn't think it is a release/change good enough for those from FM2021.

Pros:
+New details and feature (e.g. data hub with stats and data like xG and xA that tend to confuse you till you go read/Google it out).
+Changes are streamlined to make it more faster for changes/tweaks to be done on the fly (especially during match game time).
+Enjoyed the in-match control and maybe it is just me, but the VAR decisions (as annoying it could be), it is quite a fair bit of fun too.
+The good bit of FM fun is still there despite the X-th iterations.

Cons:
-FM2022 Ole is not the same as per his real-life equivalent (at least in my beta version), hahaha.
-More and more clubs getting licensed and if you don't mod it or add in the pics/emblems/logos into the game, it is really annoying and you simply will not enjoy it as much. 
-The randomness can sometimes be overwhelming to the point that you wonder if your physios are asleep or your players are simply fragile glasses that broke at the slightest contact...
-The numerous conferences/journalists will bore you as you choose the fake lines to make your whiny players happy. 
-You might not find enough changes/improvements despite the X-th iteration of release, and if you never enjoyed the past FM, chances are, it is unlikely for you to enjoy this too.

I was dubious at first, as I am a very, very casual soccer fan, but this game has actually nurtured a greater love and respect for the game as a whole. I guess this goes without saying, but 22 is my first dip into the Football Manager franchise. 

While I do think the general tutorials could be better, especially with regards to proper contract and loan negotiations. Or better yet for new people have an option for your GM to suggest a starting point for newer players in negotiations. That said, I did not feel like it was that much of a time commitment to get the bare essentials down and grow from there in regards to everything else. Make no mistake though, there is definitely a lot of depth to club management on and off the pitch. Most of which you can delegate to your a.i. staff if you wanted to however. 

The game engine is done quite well imo, while there are a few issues I have, (like the hit collision isn't super convincing), the games are more or less interesting enough to watch in real time should you choose to do so. I typically do, and a large bulk of my hours reflect that. Haha

As for a personal con, laughable to most probably, but I wish the USL-C league of the United States was playable/manageable. 123 leagues and the one team in my area isn't manageable. MLS has been fun however. Although I have learned way more about registration rules than I ever wanted to! Haha

After playing Football Manager 2021 for near 800 hours, Football Manager 2022 is an extreme improvement in all, if not most of the problems I had with previous games. The match engine feels smooth, and the players feel so alive. The amount of lovely passing moves I've scored has been top notch. Besides this, players make inaccurate first touches, which helps gameplay massively. The game, when making a dedication to play more open type of football, feels awesome. Players get tired if playing a pressing style, which is much more realistic compared to previous years.

Besides this, transfer valuations feel absolutely perfect in comparison to previous years. Last year, players would be extremely overpriced relative to what they were worth. Now, they are more realistic, with a more realistic overprice compared to before. Clubs will accept bids accordingly if they need the money. The transfer deadline day, despite being laughed upon when first announced, is a game changer. If you love harry redknapp, and want to do a bit of wheeling and dealing, the game allows you to do that. Players, much like in real life, become available on deadline day, and the transfer market feels less static, which is awesome.

The Data Hub is well put together, and if you love those Tifo IRL scattergram videos, this place is perfect for that. It's lovely knowing all the different stats of the players, and it helps you make the proper tweaks to tactics if needed. The Data is easy to understand and is explained well, so anyone can understand it.

All in all, Football Manager 2022 is a strong improvement in Football Management from the previous iteration, and the game continues to grow from strength to strength.

I played all the FM games except for FM 18-19 and FM 21. Fm 17 was a big no-no for me in terms of how similar it played out to the previous games and, I decided not to buy 18 and 19. I picked up FM 20 on epic for free just to check if there was any improvements or not, but it was totally similar again. So that's why I didn't buy FM 21. 

So when it comes to FM 22, I really couldn't hold myself and was missing the FM spirit a lot. I read a bunch of reviews on steam, so basically, everyone was saying it was a copy of FM 21. The catch was that I never played FM 21, so buying FM 22 would be a good experiment for me to see if they changed something from the previous games... And I tell you this;

Fm 22 is a HUGE improvement to any other FM games I've played, especially FM 20. It might very well be a re-skin of FM 21, but then again, I have no idea about that game, so it's totally a must-have if you want to see some changes and improvements to layouts, 3d effects, some AI improvements on negotiations, matches and what-not. 

But keep in mind that it also seems like it's coming with a bunch of broken features as well. Gegenpress is simply broken, late-time scores are super frequent, the set-pieces are a big issue in terms of how easy you can score from a far-post, 16-17-year-old youngsters bug you a lot if you don't include them in the Europa/Champions league squads, meaningless press questions before Europe matches like what I do think about a certain manager from my league getting sacked etc. 

However, I really liked what they did with post-game match analysis, engaging staff and a less-stressful inbox. I recommend this game to everyone who hasn't played FM 21 but played the previous titles. It seems like this year they've learned a good lesson.
